description.text:
A co-worker has a Traxxas JATO 3.3 radio controlled race car. He broke one of the struts and has ideas to make a custom setup. I worked with him for about an hour to sketch this up. It hasn't been printed yet but looks promising. 
Notice the "JC" for his initials built into the structure. 3D Printing for the win!
There is a support peg included to hold the ball joint up. I suggested just using a bolt through a real ball joint, but the customer insisted we try it. Clip the support off and round off as needed.
Print strong.

comments.text: very nice! im curious to know how strong it is. i have a couple rc cars that i race and im always breaking parts.

description.text:
Hello everyone!

I simply added to the existing design:

  • Two upper holes for passing the antennas of the receiver (which can be easily expanded).
  • Upper rear hole for the positioning of the Tx and antenna
  • Lower hole for the receiver.

Print it upside down as the original instructions.

author: VVSergio

print_settings.Notes:: A fairly sparse infill should be OK, but decide based on how much abuse the knob is likely to recieve.

description.text:
Created as a replacement for a knob on an old valve radio (the restoration of which unfortunately hasn't got beyond this point), this solid knob is designed to fit potentiometers with 6.3mm "D" type (flattened side) shafts. This is probably the most common size of potentiometer shaft.

The knob it was based on is the yellow one in the last image. The side grips ended up more pronounced than in the original, though this does allow for better grip.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

Cupcake CNC

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.22mm

Notes:

A fairly sparse infill should be OK, but decide based on how much abuse the knob is likely to recieve.

Acetone Smoothing

This print inspired my first attempt at using Acetone to smooth the surface of prints.

The top of the knob is concave with a shallow angle, and as can be seen in the right-most knob in the below image, the layers are very noticeable at my later height of 0.22mm. The knob in the middle was given a breif bath in Acetone (after I got impatient with the vapour technique), but ended up too greatly distorted and unevenly smoothed. The knob on the left simply had a few drops of Acetone deposited in the hollow on the top until it was sufficiently smooth. The other areas of the knob were left untreated, with an expectation that later painting would cover the layer lines visible from the side. However this painting has never been completed.

Note that the rougher side surface does make the knob easier to grip with force.

The design was made in the Pro/Desktop CAD program, a short lived spin-off from the better known Pro/Engineer, which is now called Creo. The design file is in the native ".des" format of Pro/Desktop. If you have the software, many elements should be easily adjustable.

print_settings.Notes:: 0,4 Nozzle is recommended (wall thickness)

title: Realacc diversity-module door for Fatshark DOM HD2/V3 (Updated Version)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Module bay door for the "Realacc RX5808 Pro Diversity Module
Since there was no door available for the when I ordered mine I immediately began to design my own. Now Realacc offers a injection molded door but in my opinion it is not quite pretty. I am still working on improvements and will release newer versions as soon as I am finished.

Fits in my HD2 goggles fine and should also fit the V3.

V1: Initial version, basic looks and easy to print, mostly to test the fit
V2: partly curved front to blend into the look of the goggles, no strong fixation in the bay

V2.4: some touchups, lager display cutout and snap in tabs to prevent the module from falling out, maybe sand down the corners of the nubs just a little bit because its really hard to get out otherway (just a few strokes with 450 grid).
Also added 2 additional versions with 2 holes instead of one big (you won't see the diversity LEDs underneath) one is with thick wall there (should be easier to print with some printers) the other one with a thin wall.

V2.5: Included a suggestion made by user Gc9n to feature a hole for a little buzzer. 9mm buzzers should fit nicely and with a little filing 9,6 should also. The front is left open on purpose so different length buzzers can be used



NOTE: If anyone has suggestions for improvements just post it in the comments, I can make them in the native SW format which is much easier and mostly nicer than adding something in STL.

Any suggestions for the BETA version for the Pro Plus module are welcome!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,15

Infill:

100

Notes:

0,4 Nozzle is recommended (wall thickness)

Here is another item that worked out well for me and thought I would share. I have a lake boat with a bimini top that I let someone borrow (my mistake). Anyway, the shade cover has some poorly designed connections that are weak if any part comes loose and the user is not paying attention. Bottom line, the original part broke and I cannot find the part without replacing the whole top support structure $$$$$. Anyway, this is one of the reasons I got myself a printer. A few minutes with a mic and solidworks and here you go.

I printed mine at 50% infill for strength. It fit great and will test the strength this weekend at the lake. If you happen to need one, save yourself the design time and here you go. This is for the .75in. aluminum tube support structure. Internal tube dimension of .73in. Pin connection is for .25 bolt.

This is not my invention. I found this in an article here. The original design can be found here.
http://www.instructables.com/id/10-Smartphone-to-digital-microscope-conversion/ The great person who came up with this, has a good thing here. So, I made this version that does the same thing, but from a 3D Print. You can print this in parts, and you don't need to print all the parts if you don't want to. Just the stand is good enough. You will need to get the focus lens of a cheap laser pointer. I was able to get one laser pointer for $0.94 and the other was given to me for free when I bought other things. The focus lens should fit in the hole perfectly. I made all the parts, so they should print on any printer, and not take too much plastic. You can really get amazing images from this method. Print it, use it for research, donate one to a grade school classroom. Get them out there, and hopefully we'll get more people interested in the science. I have a default model, that should work with most smartphones and one specifically for the iPhone 5 and 5s. I'll add iPhone 4, etc. If you have any suggestions please shoot them to me, or make changes yourself. Do not sell this please, JUST donate them. :-)
http://www.instructables.com/id/10-Smartphone-to-digital-microscope-conversion/

author: Kamzo

description.text:
The RepRap Wallace was my first 3D printer and it has served me well for about 4 years now. It does tend to shake around quite a bit though and in this time some of the plastic parts have cracked. I noticed aswell that it isnt the most structurally stable of designs and it relies on the weight of the printer to keep itself from twisting.
I had a load of 2020 aluminium t-slot profile lying around so decided since i have to re-print some parts for it anyway i would try and stiffen it up a bit and make it more stable by adapting the base to take this aluminium profile instead of threaded rods.

It is a work in progress and has not yet been tested. I still have to print out the new base blocks and attempt to rebuild my printer with them.

description.text:
A mount to allow off-board mounting of the Arlec AL7VA series PCB mount transformer.

Arlec are an Australian electronic components manufacturer, and this is an old model of transformer that probably hasn't been made for decades. Nevertheless, if you really just can't resist the temptation to try out my wonderful mount, you can still buy the 15V model of AL7VA transformer at this link:
http://www.rockby.com.au/catresultsSql_12.cfm?Stock_no=25677

The datasheet is included as the last picture. It doesn't appear to be online already, so this scan may be just as useful as the mount design.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

Cupcake CNC

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

Supports are included in the model.

I printed this in ABS and I suspect PLA wouldn't be strong enough as there is some force on the supporting arms, especially when the transformer is being inserted.

Hey! There are walls crossing right where the transformer is meant to go!

These are supports to help the overhanging bits at the top print. They can be removed with side cutters after the printing has finished.

Afterwards, as the transformer is slid in from one end, the "arms" can be bent out of the way of the caps where the pins are mounted, then they form a solid grip on the underside of the transformer. The mount can then be screwed or bolted to the required surface using the screw holes.

author: alikaang

description.text:
Generate it in any size.
Has an experimental feature to include an extra set of inner walls to protect the hinges from the contents. By drawing the hinge lines in a zig zag pattern, plotting time is reduced significantly.

Change doosje.pl and run it. Newest version and instructions can be found at http://github.com/Juerd/doosje Change the parameters for height, length, width and material thickness. These are the inner dimensions, so just measure the thing you want to store inside. The script will output the outer dimensions. Other customizable parameters include "finger" width and kerf compensation. Read the source code to discover more parameters. (I didn't know about http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17240, another parametric flex box, when I made this. There are quite a few differences between these two things since they were developed independently.)

remixed_from.author: raggie
remixed_from.title: Orca Series linear bearing lm8uu x-carriage - better/newest version

description.text:
Most of the files are from mendel-parts repository, with modifications to upgrade an Orca v2 in v3 (useful if you don't have built yet your v2, if it's assembled and running you may not want to take it appart).
The Sketchup file include everything.

To upgrade from a v2 to a v3 (adding linear bearings), you'll need : 10 LM8UU
8 mudgard washers 8x30 (or print them)
18 zip-tie (8 to tighten the acrylic frame, 10 for the bearings) Z-Axis :
In the v030 assembly manual, you can replace the M4x30 of the z-bearing-mount by bolts as short as M4x16 for the Z-lm8uu. Y-Axis :
Pay attention to your bed-plate and frog, the spacing of the holes is not the same from v2 to v3. X-Axis :
You'll need to remove 1-2 M4-mudgard washer on each bearing guide to accommodate the lower path of the belt.

title: Realacc RX5808  Fatshark Attitude V3 cover

description.text:
This is cover for Fatshark Attitude to fit Realacc RX5808 module.

Be ready to cut cover support extruding small parts of you Attitudes case because the module will not fit otherwise. Also you need to round a bit corners of the diversity module PCB. Visually googles case will not change. Do not be afraid to do that. Just try first to fit the module and you will see what is needed to be cut.

Cover fits very tightly, if printed with different printers deviations are possible. If module will not fit the case - try to clean inside of the cover or to scale it a bit in Cura before printing.

Cover secures by four screws, so you need drill 4 holes in your Attitudes. But do not be afraid there is noting inside at the drill points, of course do not go too deep...

For the OLED window glass I used transparent plastic ruler. It is glued with double side adhesive tape

Version9 - initial release
Version10 - few modifications (more precise bottom edges, 0.2mm more space arround the OLED module)

Solidworks Files are included for editing!

Print two sides and one strut.
Assemble spindle with M3x30mm screws through sides--or just a small finishing nail.

Welcome to Build-A-Bong Print Shop!

This workshop incorporates building block technology to our fable friend, the water pipe.

!GLASS! Down Stem is recommended if you so choose to operate this fine machinery, which I do not recommend.

Listed by Picture Slide Reel
  • Mouthpiece - Ergonomic Round
    -- 32mm tall
    -- 22mm tall
  • Extensions
    -- 100mm Pipe
    -- 200mm Pipe
  • Ice Catch
    -- 200mm Pipe
  • Percolators
    -- Jet Engine - 110mm
  • Base for 18/19mm
    -- Bubble ~ 170mm [4-5" Down Stem]
    -- Scientific ~ 170mm [4-5" Down Stem]
    --- 0 - 5 Honeycomb Percolators

Varying Version Data

  • v1.x = [Economically & Enviornmentally, Slim Strong]
    -- 5mm Thick Base
    -- 3-5mm Thick Walls

  • v2.x = [Thick & Tough]
    -- Under Development

Watertight Apparatus

  • Epoxy or Fiberglass resin may be used to paint the outer hull of your masterpiece. Thus creating a air and watertight structure.
    -- Each piece individually for changeability
    -- Threads may be coated with a light film for an airtight, watertight singularity structure
  • Wait 3 days for the resin to fully cure.

Airtight Down Stem

  • Temporary:
    --Add a light layer of aluminum foil for a temporary airtight seal.
  • Permanent:
    --Add a light layer of JB Weld to the down stem for a permanent airtight base
    ---Wait 24 hours to cure, JB Weld holds up to high temperatures

Printer settings
0.2 mm

I noticed that my Pi B3 got a little how while running so I got a little 5V fan. For that I needed a holder of some kind. But the fan was a little noisy, so I got a transistor to turn it off and on through the GPIO pins. While adding this to my mount I thought that status LED's would be nice.
The fan gives space for 3 LED (Green, Yellow, Red) and a transistor. With a little python script the temperature is read an and when then it turns on or of the leds and the fan depending on the temperature.

You need

  • 40mm 5V Fan
  • 40mm fan grill
  • 3x LED 3mm
  • 3x 56 Ohm resistor
  • 1x BC337 Transisitor
  • 4x M2,5x10mm spacer
  • 8x M2,5x4mm screws
  • 4x M2,5x16mm screws

We put all this together in a kit, including all material and a printed book. (The book is in German)
Check it out here:
https://shop.homwer.com/lueftersteuerung-kit-jugend-programmiert?c=31

author: venutalupula

description.text: So, as promised here is the customizable version of the Pencil Holder I made yesterday. Now all nice and pretty like. Plus well customizable so you can make your own for your dorm, office, ect.

Code Explanation:

Refer to the two Images above and the Code below:
A quick note before I begin, thanks for the whiteboards in the lobbies in college! It's so much nicer than just using a sheet of paper.

So, my first step in making this was defining what variables were required such that every element of this can be altered in customizer. (Okay so besides being able to allow the clip to mount horizontally, but that might come later) To know what those variables are, I referred to the dimensions I used when I first created this in inventor. There is the width of the rail, how tall/deep you want the slot to be, how much room you want to allot for the ledge, how tall you want the ledge, and most importantly how long you want it to be.
Then I addressed the visual ascetics, how rounded you want the inside, how rounded you want the outside, do you want the other bits to be rounded, and how many lines you want the fillets to be made out of.

So that worked for getting the data, and then making the blocky non rounded version wasn't that hard, just making squares and then one large linear_extrude to the slotLength.

The hard part was getting the fillets to work correctly. For this refer to the second image (the scrawled on white board). So, I came up with the module roundCorner, what it does is it operates off of 4 Booleans that allow it to make what needs to be removed or added to fillet a corner. I increase a lot of the stuff in the function by +.0001 so it looks nice once it is done.

Source Code

//BEGIN CUSTOMIZER VARIABLES
//All starting units are in in, since I'm an american and my
//dial caliper measures in inches.
/Bed Rail/

railWidth = .75;

slotHeight = 1;

innerFillet = .125;

outerFillet = .125;

/Desired Slot/

ledgeWidth = .25;
ledgeHeight = .875;
slotLength = 3;
/Advanced Stuffs/

//Basically are you using american units or real units
units_entered = 25.4;//[1:mm, 10:cm, 1000:meter, 25.4:inch, 304.8:foot]
//default is mm for most printers
desired_units_for_output = 1;//[1:mm, .1:cm, 0.001:meter, 0.0393701:inch, 0.00328084:foot]

//higher = smoother, but takes longer to render
resoultion = 42;

//thicker = more durable but longer to make.
clipThickness = .0625;

includeDefaultFillets = true;
//END CUSTOMIZER VARIABLES
//turns inches to metric
scale(units_entered/desired_units_for_output){
difference(){
union(){
TraceOutline();
roundCorners(center = [innerFillet+clipThickness,innerFillet+clipThickness], topRight = true, radi = innerFillet+.0001);
roundCorners(center = [railWidth+clipThickness-innerFillet,clipThickness+innerFillet], topLeft = true, radi = innerFillet+.0001);
}
scale([1,1,1.0001]){
translate([0,0,-.00001]){
roundCorners(center = [outerFillet,outerFillet], topRight = true, radi = outerFillet+.0001);
roundCorners(center = [railWidth+2*clipThickness-outerFillet,outerFillet], topLeft = true, radi = outerFillet+.0001);
}
}
}
}

module TraceOutline(){
difference(){
union(){
linear_extrude(slotLength){
square(size = [railWidth+2clipThickness,clipThickness]);
square(size = [clipThickness,slotHeight+2clipThickness]);
translate([railWidth+clipThickness, 0]){
square(size = [clipThickness,slotHeight+2clipThickness]);
}
translate([railWidth+clipThickness, slotHeight+clipThickness]){
square(size = [ledgeWidth+2clipThickness,clipThickness]);
}
translate([railWidth+ledgeWidth+clipThickness2, slotHeight-ledgeHeight+clipThickness]){
square(size = [clipThickness,railWidth+2clipThickness]);
}
}
if(includeDefaultFillets){
addDefaultFillets();
}
}
if(includeDefaultFillets){
scale([1,1,1.0001]){
translate([0,0,-.00001]){
cutDefaultFillets();
}
}
}
}
}

module addDefaultFillets(){
//4
roundCorners(center = [1.5clipThickness + railWidth + ledgeWidth, slotHeight + .5clipThickness], bottomLeft = true, radi = clipThickness/2+.0001);
//5
roundCorners(center = [2.5clipThickness + railWidth, slotHeight + .5clipThickness], bottomRight = true, radi = clipThickness/2+.0001);
}

module cutDefaultFillets(){
//1
roundCorners(center = [2.5clipThickness + railWidth + ledgeWidth, slotHeight - ledgeHeight + 1.5clipThickness], topLeft = true, topRight = true, radi = clipThickness/2+.0001);
//2
roundCorners(center = [2.5clipThickness + railWidth + ledgeWidth, slotHeight + 1.5clipThickness], bottomLeft = true, radi = clipThickness/2+.0001);
//3
roundCorners(center = [1.5clipThickness + railWidth, slotHeight + 1.5clipThickness], bottomRight = true, radi = clipThickness/2+.0001);
//6
roundCorners(center = [.5clipThickness, slotHeight + 1.5clipThickness], bottomLeft = true, bottomRight = true, radi = clipThickness/2+.0001);
}

module roundCorners(center = [0,0], topLeft = false, topRight = false, bottomLeft = false, bottomRight = false, radi = .125){
translate([center[0],center[1],0]){
difference(){
union(){
if(topLeft){
rotate([0,0,270]){
cube([radi,radi,slotLength]);
}
}
if(topRight){
rotate([0,0,180]){
cube([radi,radi,slotLength]);
}
}
if(bottomLeft){
rotate([0,0,0]){
cube([radi,radi,slotLength]);
}
}
if(bottomRight){
rotate([0,0,90]){
cube([radi,radi,slotLength]);
}
}
}
translate([0,0,-.00001]){
cylinder(r=radi, h = slotLength+.0001, $fn=resoultion);
}
}
}
}

description.text:
This is a placeholder for the Aus3D infra-red probe / sensor, used for automatic bed levelling. This should make it easier to design custom adapters or mounts to attach it to different printers.

These probes can be mounted to any printer with an E3D V6 / Lite6 / Chimera / Cyclops HotEnd without any special adapter or mounting hardware. For printers with other HotEnds, an adapter might be needed - I'm compiling a list of mounting solutions people have designed here, and hopefully this model is handy for anyone designing their own.

A drawing for mounting / dimensions is also attached, and more details can be found on the wiki page here.

This object is designed to firmly clip onto the metal rail across the top of a standard cubicle wall. It should click into place and fit very snugly. Once in place, you can hang objects off of the built-in hoops. This thing was made with Tinkercad. This object is easily modified. I have used it to vertically mount very large 3D prints above a cubicle wall. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/3HLSlZT0OqC NOTE: It is critical that the object is printed on its side. Because the clips bend slightly before snapping into place, the bend cannot be parallel with the layers or it'll break.

Print, cool, trim any excess. Place the item on top of the cubicle wall. Push down on the back end so where the nub is just past the metal lip. Push down on the front end. You should hear a very satisfying click as it tightly adheres to the top of your cubicle wall. If it does not adhere tightly, something is wrong. This thing is incredibly secure.  
For removal, you may need to use a flathead screwdriver to gently pull one side away from the wall.  
You can modify this item with other types of mounts. I have used a semi-circle to hold a very large bust of a Voronoi Yoda to the top of my cubicle. I'll be posting pictures shortly.

print_settings.Notes:: It's important to print the top with a raft and supports. There's just too much overhang otherwise! That's why I separated them into two STL files. The base prints just fine.

author: gidio

description.text:
I'm starting the process of filling out the kitchen of the Dirty Goat Tavern. This bread oven was designed after looking at a large number of paintings and real bread ovens from the middle ages. It can take a cut down tea light in the interior to give it a really beautiful flickering fire glow.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

How to prepare the light

I used Holiday Time Tea Lights but you can really get away with any tea lights you want, or even just buy a batch of flickering LEDs from Evil Mad Scientist (I know for a fact flickering red and flickering yellow together look amazing).

If you use just raw LEDs, tape the leads (yes, seriously, tape) to either side of a CR 2032 battery, and it should last for like a week.

If you want to use the tea lights, you get the advantage that they have an on and off switch. The pictures below tell how to prepare a holiday time tea light for the oven.

Get your Holiday Time Tea lights Pop open the case use some snips to cut around the edge. Be sure not to break the case for the switch or the battery case. Clipped around one side Fully clipped Dry fit the tea light in the oven, for Holiday time, it will only fit in one orientation. Paint the base in black paint. Cover the LED and the part of the base you will face forward in hot glue. While it is still tacky, muss up the surface to both make it look like flame, and to diffuse the light coming off the LED.

description.text: A Pythagorean cup (also known as a Pythagoras cup, a Greedy Cup or a Tantalus cup) is a form of drinking cup which forces its user to imbibe only in moderation. Credited to Pythagoras of Samos, it allows the user to fill the cup with wine up to a certain level. If the user fills the cup only up to that level he may enjoy his drink in peace. If he exhibits gluttony, however, the cup spills its entire contents out the bottom (the intention being: onto the lap of the immodest drinker).

The throttle on the first generation (2010/2011) BMW S1000RR is very stiff to turn. This is because of the spring on the throttle bodies. This bracket allows the spring to be unwound by about 120 degrees, thereby softening the amount of effort required to twist the throttle.

This bracket is designed to go over top of the bracket already installed to hold the throttle cable. It is best to add some blue threadlock to the 2 screws, and to take care not to over-tighten these screws.

The temperature in this area of the engine should be less than 150 F. The airbox goes right overtop the throttle bodies and the airbox is made of plastic. Plus there is constant air flow to keep the throttle bodies cool.

ABS should work (not PLA). I found that the ideal material to print this in is Colorfabb HT. This is because it has a Glass Temperature of over 100 degrees celsius. This is higher than ABS, but lower than PolyCarbonate. The higher the heat resistance the better, however the bracket should not be too rigid (as in PolyCarbonate) otherwise it would break when the screws are tightened.

description.text:
This week we are laser cutting and engraving an awesome wooden toy airplane on our Speedy 300 laser machine! We use 1/8" MDF wood.

We made this plane in our TroSpace Makerspace in our facility in Calgary, AB. The space is open for educators and those in the Makerspace and Fablab movements.

Printer:

Trotec Speedy 300 Laser

Step 1: Download Artwork File

You can download the artwork file as an CorelDraw or Adobe Illustrator file. The red hairline outline (0.001") represents the the cut line and should be RBG Red, and the fill RBG Black and Turquoise are the different engraving levels.

Step 2: Laser cut and engrave

We used the Speedy 300 flexx laser machine (60w) to cut and engrave the 1/8" MDF wood.

Engraving setting: 85 Power, 85 Speed
Cutting setting: 85 Power, 0.9 Speed

Laser Engrave the MDF Laser Cut the MDF Step 3: Assembly

There aren't a lot of parts so assembly is minimal. You would need crazy glue to glue together all the parts and hinges.

print_settings.Notes:: The lower cooler is quite thin, and your printer must be fairly accurate. However, I am working on a second version to increase thickness slightly, and to give a little more room off the hot ends.

description.text:
In an effort to gain more accuracy out of my printer, and gain the ability to print in dual colors, I've come up with this design.

I also felt that I would be able to gain some printing speed by decreasing the moving mass on the print head.

I've tried to keep the hot ends as close together as possible, so as not to lose build space. Both nozzles have access to the entire build plate.

Also, the auto level servo mount was designed to not lose space or interfere with the side of the machine. You MUST route your heating and thermistor wires carefully so that they don't hit the frame when homing the X axis or on the far side of the build plate.

This design, like several others, deflects hot end cooling air out the sides of the mount, keeping it away from the build plate.

I also have found that most small servos have quite a bit of slop in the gear train. Most of the servo arm designs I've seen have the button on the switch offset from the center line of the servo shaft. When the switch hits the build plate, the force causes the arm rotate slightly (taking up the slop), thereby changing the actual reading each time it hits the plate. By keeping the switch button of the switch in line with the shaft of the servo, forces are applied more to the shaft bearing surfaces and not to the gear train. You get less deflection/movement during auto level operations (this one change made a HUGE difference in my auto level / printing). I've included 2 servo arms. The arm with holes was designed around MY switch. I urge you to print the arm WITHOUT holes and use your switch as a template to drill mounting holes.

IMPORTANT!!
During assembly I found that the servo mount was hitting the X drive belt. I had to insert washers between the back of the carriage and the servo mount to clear the belt. I am working on a new design to fix this.

MISC NOTES:

I printed everything in PLA. I have not seen any melting issues with the mounts yet, but I run the hot end fans all the time.
When running dual extruders, the RAMPS board does not have a way to turn on / throttle the work piece cooling fan. You need an extender board. I have one on order, but right now I have my cooling fan tied to voltage through a switch.... I have to manually turn it on when needed, and it only runs at full speed. I'm only printing in PLA, so after the first layer, I turn it on.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 or .3

Infill:

Yes

Notes:

For rigidity, I used fairly high infill amounts. I also used 3 perimeters, and 3 bottom/top layers.
On the extruder mount, I think i used 75% infill and higher layers to keep the zipties from breaking the mount. Don't over tighten them or it will break.

The lower cooler is quite thin, and your printer must be fairly accurate. However, I am working on a second version to increase thickness slightly, and to give a little more room off the hot ends.

Some clean up may be needed. I've tried to make the use of supports as little as possible. The only place needed was for the lower cooler slot, lower cooler duct and the holes for the nut locations.

The extruder mount has channels for the zip ties to pass through. The channels aren't that big, so most printers should be able to bridge without issues.

For the hot end mount:
After printing, my hot ends fit perfect in the opening, and when tightened down, do not move. However, if yours do move, you may need to gently sand the mating faces (not the half circles) a little to give some more clamping force.

The mount was designed to give 32mm spacing between nozzle openings. After printing a couple of things, they are off a teeny, tiny amount. I am still playing with the offset amounts in my printing software, but it's down to about .01mm. Just enough feel a difference in colors.

This was designed in Sketchup, and printed using Simplify3D.

I am trying to find the original things I used to give me parts and ideas for this entire design. When I find them I will give proper credit. In the mean time, THANKS to everyone who's parts I got inspiration from!!

I am really limited on my access to hardware (deployed in the middle east), so I've tried to reuse existing hardware from the Anet A8 kit as much as possible. Hence the zip ties for securing the extruder motors to the mount. I used the cooling fans that came with the hot ends.

The 50mm fan is friction fitted to upper cooling duct (which is also friction fit to the lower duct). You could add a drop of glue if you feel it's needed. It also uses one bolt screwed into the rear mount. There is no mount hole designed into my rear mount. I simply drilled a small hole in it using the fan as a guide. It doesn't take much to hold the fan in place, so don't over tighten the bolt. I may upload a new version of the rear mount with a nut location.

The extruder mount mounts to the rear of the cross piece using the holes and hardware that held the original display. I have converted to a RAMPS setup, so I no longer use that display.

I reused existing hardware when possible. However, you may need to purchase a few things.

The hot ends I purchased included the air fittings, tubing, thermistors, heat cartridges, fan ducts, and cooling fans. I did not use the ducts.

After tightening everything on the hot ends, mine came up about .8mm difference in length from the tip of the nozzle to the end of the housing (minus air fittings). The mount allows each hot end to move up and down about .5mm so it's pretty easy to get them both the same distance from the build plate.

Here's what I purchased off Amazon for this conversion:

2 X J head hot end:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B010MSTVZO/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

1 X MK8 Extruder:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B011QCFGPO/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s03?ie=UTF8&psc=1

M2 / M3 hardware kit:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B014OO5KQG/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s02?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I also purchased these, but these are optional (although I'm finding they do help):

Anycubic Barrel Stainless Steel Nozzle Throat with PTFE Tube:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0188G31AS/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s03?ie=UTF8&psc=1

author: andreas

description.text:
The Ultimaker 2 Filament Sensor detect problems with feeding filament, such as skids, filament distance and a stuck of filament.

The hardware is printed and the electrically parts are standard components.
Everything you need is:
2 half usb cables, ~1m, male
6 screws 3x7mm
3 transmissive optical sensors (TCST 2103): http://www.produktinfo.conrad.com/datenblaetter/175000-199999/184250-da-01-en-GABELLICHT_TCST_2103__VIS.pdf
and some resistors (150, 330 and 33k3 Ohms worked for me)

The dual optical measurement of the filament sensor detects also the direction! How the sensor does this? With a X4 encoding described here: http://www.dynapar.com/Technology/Encoder_Basics/Quadrature_Encoder/

Hack: fix a elastic band onto the roll, so the filament does't slip.
Use the standard ultimaker's 2.85 mm filament as a more robust axis.

so long he didnt know thats the print is running the turning sensor would recognize a stop and the print could not start !

comments.author: Luchador

comments.text:
I made changes to detect whether it is printing or not. It's called "Printing" and is a derived value from the filament distance as well as a timeout:
0 means not printing
1 means printing
-1 means the measurement was stopped

description.text:
Saw a video of a similar thing on YouTube but the guy had no link to the STL files. So broke out Sketchup and designed them from scratch.

Designed to snap fit around the 8mm smooth Y Axis rod between the two LM8UU bearings. (See image).

Can be used with ANY printer that uses an 8mm rod.

Printer:

Geeetech Full Metal Aluminum

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

For better adhesion you can use a BRIM - No raft please as it spoils the profile. No supports needed.

Just cut 2X pieces of sponge like from a dishwashing sponge the length of the model and about 10mm high. Put one each on either side and impregnate with thin machine oil. Snap fit as shown around the 8mm rod and with the printer Y movement, it will self oil the rod.

description.text:
A minimalistic battery holder for AA and AAA batteries. It was designed to tidy up my chaotic pile of spare batteries at home without needing additional space.
They can be stacked to give the batteries even more hold if wanted (as shown in one of the pictures).

It was designed for a 0.4mm nozzle. So every wall is two lines thick.

When printing the one for AAA, remember to set the slicer to

  • 0 bottom layer
  • 2 perimeter layers
  • 2 top layers
  • 0% infill
    I have no clue, but the 3D design software wasn't able to do it like it was with the AA batteries.

description.text:
Added some parts to go with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:906046 to lock the pod down at the front of the canopy (a thumb nut, washer and fixture). Also a slim, slightly down tilted Mobius mount that can be screwed on top of the pod in place of the servo gimbal.

I run my Mobius as a live feed via a USB connector through a Naze 32 with OSD to a 5.8GHz VTX.

• Guidelines: print out of elastic material.

  • Notes: Sparse Geometric patterning and embedded alternating angles between nodes facilitate buckling and thus vibration/noise absorption.

A short piece of heat-shrink tube on the top of the z screw helped a bit with the rattling.

comments.text: Great job! Just dont try to explain to teenagers why a ball screw has both sides end support and that floating end does not mean an end without support
comments.author: silyavski

comments.text: You actually dont need this, since the rods are directly attached to the nema motor and not like other printers with couplers.
comments.author: Gardriel

comments.text:
good to hear that someone else knows what i have to do to make my printer more silent!
You can believe me, i know that it isn't needed, but the trapezoid screw will start to wobble in high power mode. Because of this, it's an easy way to stop wobbling when you use another holder that supports a bearing.
Nobody said you have to change it on your printer, for me it works and that's all i want.
comments.author: Gardriel

comments.text: There is a good reason for the z screw to float. Alignment is provided by the rods not by the z screw.
comments.author: sipo75

comments.text: Whats the problem here? Why it's wrong to use a bearing to make the build more quiet?
comments.author: sipo75

comments.text: If you constrain the z-screws on the top you are causing strain on the whole z system. You can not align four elements (the two z-rods and the two z-screws) to be perfectly aligned. As long as only the rods are constrained (as designed) the z-screw can compensate any misalignment. You can see this if you move from z = 0 mm to z = 200 mm the position inside the "too big" hole will change. If the z-screw can't move there will be a constraining force probably wearing the bearings (laterally) a bit faster and unevenly.
comments.author: rfeierabend

These are upgrade files for the Orca 0.3 to change the z-axis to linear bearings.
The nut traps are slightly higher, due to the 1.25-ish millimetres difference between the ball bearings and linear bearings.
The nut trap files are for two different nuts, one standard, and one 24mm long.
Just an FYI, the quality of the prints has increased dramatically since this mod; I no longer get shifts each layer. Each layer is 'almost' exactly the same position. (see pictures)

Print two(2) of the required nut trap. Assemble and fit to machine. Realign and tighten up.

title: Colonial Marines Motion Tracker M314 (Aliens) Ripley, Hicks

description.text:
This is a replica of the Motion tracker used by the Colonial Marines and Ripley in the film Aliens. It's full sized and is designed to be used as a cosplay or display item.

I have included a PDF instruction manual which shows step-by-step how to assemble it, and a PDF to print out the screen and button graphics to fit the finished Tracker.

ENJOY!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Replicator Dual

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

I have printed all these and made at least 6 full trackers from these files. I would suggest printing at your favourite settings, and you may need a bit of trial and error to get them right.

I have made this both from ABS and PLA and to be honest there's little difference, I think ABS can get you a nicer finish with less work.

I did design this with a hollow body and hollow 'viewer screen', so if you're that way minded you can install electronics in it and make it beep and things like the real one! The bottom cap can be unscrewed to serve as a battery housing.

Optional Extras

The sling swivels I use on the finished ones are the Bisley make that are shown In the PDF manual. However, I also designed a set of plastic ones if you just want this as a display item, that will work fine for you. I've also included a stand so you can put the Tracker on display.

Additional things required!

To make the tracker you'll need:

  • Glue of some sort
  • Black cable wire (like from a mains cable)
  • Thinner black wire (like from headphones)
  • 3mm screws (see manual)
  • Paint
  • Printed graphics (see PDF), I print them on acetate for the best look.
  • Heat shrink tubing to fit the cables you've got

I've been working to improve the print quality of my printer. After trying everything I could think of, someone mentioned that the flexible metal couplers can compress and stretch, resulting in Z artifacts. So I decided to replace them with stiff couplers. This is a replacement stiff coupler between a 5mm and 8mm shaft, as found on the MendelMax 2.0. I use these in conjunction with OhmEye's Z isolators: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/3uyotd400xp2ef5/2pLnjCypcV/STLs/Z%20Isolators/ohmeye_mm2_isolator_release%202x.STL With this combination, my print quality is the best I've had so far.

If your stepper motors have a flat (as most do), print two of each part. Otherwise print four of the Z_Split_Coupler part. Then use a pair of M3 x 16 screws and M3 Nyloc nuts for each coupler to hold them together. Using Nyloc nuts instead of regular M3 nots will allow them to stay tight, even with all the motion of the Z axis.

comments.text:
Hi John, I have Got the same problem with Ohmeye's isolator and I'm going to print your files.....
But just a question did you constrain the screw with 608zz Bearing, to the bottom of the screw?
comments.author: Djamuka

comments.text: There is no need for a constraint at the bottom. I'm using Ohmeye's isolator with these stiff couplers, and the screws don't move very much.
comments.author: Djamuka

comments.text: Thanks print quality are better than before with coupler....
comments.author: JohnSL

comments.text:
The disadvantage to a stiff coupler is that if your Z axis screws have any bend in them at all, that bend will be translated to z axis wobble.
In theory, the best approach would be to use a flexible coupler along with a thrust bearing, so that the coupler's length is constrained.
comments.author: raldrich

comments.text: Although any Z-axis wobble should be removed if used in conjunction with OhmEye's "Z isolators" :)
comments.author: raldrich

title: Teach Measurement by Making Your Own Ruler!

description.text:
The goal of this lesson is to teach students how to use a ruler by teaching them the concept of the parts of an inch. Understanding an inch can be tough for kids. The different sizes that can make up an inch is even harder because they're expressed as fractions. This model is much bigger than an inch so it's also important to review the concept of scale. It's important that student know this is a representation and not an actual inch.

This model can be easily manipulated. It, not only, teaches the parts of an inch but the relationship between the smaller parts. For example, two 1/4 inch pieces are the same size as one 1/2 inch piece.

Part two of this lesson would be having student design their own ruler.

Here it is:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1733620

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.03

Infill:

10%

Notes:

These parts take a few hours to print but work well once they're done.

If students build a ruler using a 3D printer and can then manipulate the parts they'll have a better conceptual understanding of measurement. Overview and Background Students will use 3D printed measurement manipulatives to develop a conceptual understanding of the parts of an inch. They will understand the relationship between different size representations and how they relate to each other. Objectives
Students will be able to conceptualize the parts of an inch. Standards:
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.3.MD.B.4
Generate measurement data by measuring lengths using rulers marked with halves and fourths of an inch. Show the data by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in appropriate units— whole numbers, halves, or quarters.

This lesson involves students using 3D printed manipulatives more than them designing anything. they'll get to design something in part 2 of this lesson. Part one of this lesson should take one class period. 
Ok now have students use the manipulatives. Ask them what they notice about the different pieces and how they relate to each other. Hopefully they are able to see how many of each pice fit together to make an inch. I would them ask them how many pieces fit into each other. You can make up your own handout for this since you know your students better than anyone. 
Next steps would be to have them make a ruler of their own design. The idea is that they understand that an has 2 halves, 4 quarters and eight eights. they can represent that anyway they want.

Before and after of lesson. I would have the students take a short quiz on the parts of a ruler to get an idea of what they know. This site goes to 1/16 of an inch so this site maybe best suited for higher grades.
http://www.rulergame.net/ Softschools.com has a good game as well.
http://www.softschools.com/measurement/games/ruler/inch_ruler/ This is a great picture to illustrate the point.
https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/564x/68/e0/60/68e06064aec55a18320883eedeac695a.jpg Its a bit small but you can enlarge it. I use this hand out because it's a great way to introduce the concept. The song can be fun too. This website is a great resource for math quizzes in general but if you select the number line in the Fractions->Identify section it's pretty much a ruler. From here I would take my pre vs. post tests to compare what my students learned. https://www.thatquiz.org/tq-6/math/identify/fractions/

title: Aero-tek P'tiot - Piko BLX slim conversion

description.text:
What-is it?

3D printed parts to convert aero-tek "Le P'tiot" quadcopter to a slim profile using Piko BLX flight controller

Benefits

Integrated PDB allows a thinner body and cleaner wiring
Saves some weight (=~10%)
Battery is nearer to the COG
Camera can be adjusted with higher tilt without the frame obstructing the view

Post-printing

You will need to cut an opening in the upper frame for the camera tilt, and shorten the provided screws

Parts

Aero-tek Ptiot: http://aero-tek.eu/shop/fr/packs-et-kits/216-p-tiot-fpv-complet-a-monter.html
Furious FPV Piko BLX: http://furiousfpv.com/product_info.php?products_id=41
There's just enough place for a naked D4R-II or X4R-SB Frsky receiver, but I'd recommand using a micro-rx to save space and weight (eg. for a buzzer)

Update 2017-02-19

Added holes for screws to the camera support, so that the camera doesn't shift angle so easily
Adjusted the arm's endstop height

title: Polargraph - timing belt and spring load

description.text:
My take on a polargraph shown on Aarhus Mini Maker Fair Oct. 2016. Featuring:
1) Spring loaded bearing minimizing/removing belt slip
2) Screw mount (3 parts per side)
3) Suction cup mount (2 parts per side). Mirror parts for mounting electronics on the left hand side.
4) PCB for two steppers and servo (My old EggBot PCB is reused and attached for Eagle)

I used two Alu single suction pad (50kg) from Silverline (http://www.silverlinetools.com/en-GB/Products/Automotive/Bodywork/427574)

I have been building on the wonderful work of Sandy Noble (http://www.polargraph.co.uk/) and run with polargraph software on my machines.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

RepRapPro

Infill:

40%

Assembly

Assembly for wood:

  • Mount bearing on arm (large hole).
  • Mount arm on motor mount (the low stub) - ensure free movement.
  • Insert a 20mm M3 bolt with a holding M3 nut for holding the spring into the spring arm.
  • Add a spring for load (it do not need a lot of force.) over the bolt and fit in to the groove on the spring arm.
  • Mount motor and adjust pulleys to be flush with the surface.
  • Mount on wood board.
  • Mount the Arduino in a suitable holder on the wood board (e.g. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33327 or http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1826386 or just pick one...).

Assembly for suction pads:

  • Mount bearing on arm (large hole).
  • Mount arm on motor mount (the low stub) - ensure free movement.
  • Insert a 20mm M3 bolt with a holding M3 nut for holding the spring into the spring arm.
  • Add a spring for load (it do not need a lot of force.) over the bolt and fit in to the groove on the spring arm.
  • Mount motor and adjust pulleys to be flush with the surface.
  • Mount Arduino on right hand bracket.
  • Mount plate on suction cup and mount motor mount on plate.
  • Mount the two lags (with M3 nuts inserted) onto the Arduino.

Assembly of gondola:

  • Mount the servo (upside down) on the two stubs
  • Zip tie the timing belt onto itself making a loop that slides freely over the two stubs on the sides. You could add an 608zz bearing if you feel like - I did not and it draws fine.
  • Insert a M3 nut in to the pen ring and screw in a 20mm M3 bolt.

Assemble electronics:

  • See image of electronics and copy
  • Using the polargraph firm. (http://www.polargraph.co.uk/) with these pin settings:
    Motor A= Left and Motor B=Right
    Left Enable = 2
    Left Step = 3
    Left Dir = 4
    Right Enable = 5
    Right Step = 6
    Right Dir = 7
    Servo = 11

Connect electronics to servo, motors, PSU and computer. Use modular wiring so extensions can be archived very easy. My timing belt is 6m long on each side for the suction pad version and around 2m for the wood version. Wires have to fit to this.

Play and enjoy - it is so funny....

description.text:
My cats have the nasty habbit to bring live mice inside the house and let them go (to hunt them later I suppose). Anyway my cat flap cam registered their latest victim trying to get out and I felt a bit sorry for the little animal.

According to the numerous fotos my cam sent, the mouse kept around the cat flap, maybe trying to get out the way it came in? It gave me the idea to install a mouse escape hatch (or less dramatic; a mouse flap).

It only has to be a simple flap, just a one-way opening to provide an exit for the trapped prey. Spent a little time with OpenSCAD (http://www.openscad.org) to design this.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3
